number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2013
												I waited until the early access phase had ended and until the game was in full release. I have to say; this is by far the most polished and refined zombie survival sandbox experience I've ever had. The only limitations I belive it had was its budget; things such as amazing graphics -not that they're bad -I'm just used to high end AAA titles which boast amazing visuals. Knowing that the budget wasn't massive; Undead labs have reached for something quite ambitious. Have they pulled it off? I belive they have. This game is immersive and has enough variety between missions and sidemissions for it not to feel like a 'grinding' or 'mechanical' use of your time but an meaningful and deeply engaging experience.The great thing about it is you get the hoard fighting feel of L4D2 without the sense that you're just passing through but actually warding off hoards to defend yourself or your home. And when people die -espcially characters you put a good deal of time into; well it's meaningful; not in a tear to the eye way the Walking Dead boasts but in a way which means something to you because you played through the experience of the game, trained that character, equpped them, knew their skills and hobbies, had seen them interact with others and that's why it sucks when they die -not just because the narrative told you it was sad but because of the time you invested in that character. Thankfully the permadeath system does not halt your gaming experience but reverts you to alternate characters within your home base. Every decision you make and even to an extent, the WAY you carry out that decision (eg: reckless driving, putting things off too long or even friendly fire) can really make a difference to how the characters in the game react to you and the situation. Ammo is fairly rare and weapons arn't that common themselves, so you have to really mean it when you choose to draw your weapon instead of using melee combat -which makes the guns feel so much more desirable and your persona far more secure when you use them. Thankfully they're not too rare so if you miss a shot or decide to shoot a zombie that you'll fell bad.It isn't a complete sandbox like DayZ, there are missions and randomly generated side missions which keep coming so while you're free to prioritize hunting ammo or supplies you'll never have a sense of aimlessness.There is an element of stratergy invovled with SOD when it comes to upgrading and deligating resources for differrent things; do you want to prioritize defences around the perimiter of your homebase? Or is putting resources into a family dining arrangement to avoid discord within the walls of your base more important to you? There are many other decisions you can make with the investment of your resources which will directly impact on the readiness of your characters, weapons and vehicles when they are called upon.It's a pretty slow start and will initially require some more patience than the opening segments of most games but by the time you're 2 hours in you won't want to stop playing. It's managed to even pull me away from the latest release in my favourite game frachise ever within a month of it's release -the game I built this high end machine to play. And yet I find myself perfectly content lobbing off zombie's heads, or jumping in a car and running over zombies hordes at a time.SOD is an immersive, meaningful and addictive gaming experience which gives back so much more than what you pay for it by the gaming industry's standards today. Having said that I'm the kind of gamer who will persevere with what others consider to be punishing and sometimes repetitive games which demand persistence and patience such as Metro 2033, Far Cry 2 and the original Assasin's Creed. All things considered (including the liklely budget for the developers) I can not fault State of Decay. Personally; I'd give it a 10/10.

												I had my doubts about State of Decay, suspecting yet another shark hunting the blood of Day Z fans.  I was wrong, and I am very happy to be wrong.  I enjoy this. content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												It's a decent game, but I'm still giving this one as well as the Breakdown DLC a thumbs down.The game starts out quite promising, but turns out to be repetitive and boring as soon as you've established a decent home base. The zombie sandbox seems vast at first, but excitement fades when you realize that the houses are pretty much the same everywhere. There aren't that many interesting items or people to find. And even though Breakdown seemingly adds more challenge to the game, things get pretty easy as soon as you've established a home base and started upgrading your characters. Your neighbors are super needy, you constantly need new equipment for your home base and there's always some shmuck that has to be saved or a zombie horde that has to be mowed down. In the end you just drive repetitively from one waypoint to another until you've helped everyone with their needy needs and the game is over.At worst the zombies are mildly annoying. The fight system doesn't offer much immersion. You just keep clicking and "smash spacebar not to die". The game would have benefited from a more hands on fight system like they had in Condemned.State of Decay had some redeeming qualities, mainly the way you're able to earn people's trust and create a community of survivors. The scripted events breathe life into the characters who are actually able to do some useful stuff on their own while you're completing missions. And if they die you can't bring them back. The graphics are pretty okay and there's a satisfying POK sound when your baseball bat hits an armored zombie's helmet.The game is very ambitious, and while it doesn't suck horribly, I still feel it falls short.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												I really like how this game focuses on survival and fighting off zombies. Once you build a community you have to go out and gather ressources to survive, and don't be careless out there because you will get overrun and killed. The fighting system is really simple and fun wether you choose to go melee or use guns. The zombies animations and movements are nice and fluid and thier artificial intelligence is simple and well done. They react to sound and light and will run to you if you make too much noise. You can still sneak around them, especially in the dark and score a few stealth melee kills wich is always nice. I also like how you can choose to build your community by finding more survivor, controlling certain characters to level them up and get them to learn new abilities and be stronger. You have quite a big map to explore as well, a lot of scavenging to do. You have to be carefull to keep the zombie population in check around your home base so it doesn't get overrun. The gameplay is really fun and well done. And of course, among all of that, you have a nice little quest story line that gets you to learn about what  happened and what caused all this. Although not everything is answered at the end of the game it opens the door for a nice sequel or expansion. I give this game a 9 out of 10 because the only downside is that you cannot bring your friends to play with you in co-op... how awesome would it have been.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												For the price, this is a fantastic game. Although 28 hours in, I still haven't beaten it yet, I feel like I've put enough time in to give it a fair review. This game combines base building and team management mechanics like X-Com, with open world driving and shooting like Saints Row or GTA. Each survivor in your team has his/her own skills, gear, and traits, and once you've made friends with them, they can be played. There are also perks you can unlock as you go through the game, like vehicle delivery, calling for backup, etc.As you go through the game, you discover vantage points that let you reveal points of interest like places to scavenge, other survivors and their enclaves, potential new base locations, and zombie hordes or special zombies.There are a few minor pathfinding glitches here and there, with characters getting clogged up in doorways or spawning in odd places, but none of them are game breaking. The game also features permadeath with auto-save, so you find yourself trying to be extra careful not taking unnecessary risks and protecting your survivors. Sometimes they get sick, or can get defeated when they're out and about. For this reason, it pays to switch characters often and keep each member leveled and geared. Focus on one, and you might lose them to a freak accident, get overwhelmed, or they might get sick and die. There are also morale issues that come up if you neglect one of your survivors. Play as them and do a few good deeds and they'll be back in fighting form. Survivors can also be specialized, unlocking special moves when using certain types of weapons, or various bonuses.The game isn't too terribly difficult if you're careful, don't take too many risks, and always keep ammo and consumables on hand. There are no difficulty options, but the Breakdown DLC allows you to replay the game at progressively higher difficulties (fewer resources, more/tougher zombies, etc.).I'm pretty hooked on this game. It has interesting mechanics and a mix of gameplay elements that seem to hit all the right notes for me. There are a few things that keep me from giving it a perfect 10: Lack of character creation or customization (wardrobe, hair, face, skills, etc.), no relationships (romance options, friendships between survivors), and you're limited to one map. Now, the map is pretty big, and resources, events, and the location of some of the NPC's are different on each playthrough. The keyboard/mouse controls are excellent, and for everything except driving, seem to work better than a gamepad. The interface is a little clunky though, and it's not always obvious how to build certain types of skills like cooking, medicine, or even what certain skills do. A bit more feedback or explanation would be helpful. The lack of co-op multiplayer is also noticable. You can take survivors with you as you run around, but they fatigue quickly, they don't gain XP or morale, and they ditch you as soon as you start a mission. Overall I'd have to give this one a solid 8/10. If you're a fan of open world games with base building and team maangement, you can't go wrong with this one. It's a blast!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This game is fairly straight forward, you switch between a number of survivors in the zombie apocalypse where you must seek out resources and fight off zombies to preserve and expand your base. Your resources dwindle day by day and you must be strategic in prioritizing which resources you pursue. This game excels because of its simplicity but that simplicity unfortunately leads to the game becoming repetative later on with no clear goals and no further progression. The underlying mechanics of the game remind me of mobile games but with much stronger graphics and interface. The game feels repetitive once you have an established base and full group of survivors, which can happen pretty quickly if you want it to. At this point you're really just playing to keep the game going because while there is a story mode there is no clear objective besides just surviving. The game would really benefit from a more comprehensive base building element or something that maybe gives you a sense of rebuilding society or fighting back a gainst the zombies in a meaningful way, but then I guess it deviate from the norms of the zombie-sirvival genre. Zombies just keep spawning and after a point you'll feel like you've killed more zombies than the population of the little country towns of the setting. Combat leans more in favor of melee as noises will draw the hordes. I like the combat mechanics that give you the right level of contectual animation, when you swing at a hoard of zombies the way you swing takes into consideration how you're moving and how the zombies are moving around you. Driving takes a little getting used to but reminds me of how the driving feels in the GTA games. Vehicles are as much a resources as ammunition, food, medical, and building supplies with a finite number of them that dwindle as you wreck them. People are also as much a resource that you must weigh whether to allow them into your group and if and when you prioritize aid over your own resource gathering.I bought the game for $7 and its worth a bit more than that, but not too much.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												I held off reviewing this game for a year because when I first bought it, State of Decay was so absolutely epic that I thought it was too good to be true. Well, one year later, after I've had time to process this game all I can say is this:This game is the greatest zombie apocalypse simulator ever made. I've never played a game that even comes close to the pure genius that is State of Decay (Sorry DayZ fans, but no contest here). While I admit the graphics in this game are a bit dated, there are a few annoying but minor glitches, and after many many hours of this game it can start to feel repetitive but everything else more than makes up for it. The controls are reminiscent of Resident Evil 4, the atmostphere is similar to that of The Walking Dead, and the ability to control an entire group of survivors trying to survive a zombie apocalypse is just the icing on the cake. If you don't already have this game do yourself a favor and BUY IT NOW (At the time of this review it is currently 75% off the base game and both DLC) I also recommend the Breakdown DLC if you're looking for more of a challenge and the Lifeline DLC for an entirely new story. Overall Review:+Brilliant Game Design+Amazing Atmosphere+Hours of Replayability-Slightly Dated Graphics/Minor Glitches9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Do not take notice of the 1 hour playtime, I have worked my xbox to death playing this game. This review will focus on the gamplay and mechanics, story is not as important for this game. Lets start the review!When State of Decay first appeared on my Xbox 360 dashboard I thought of it as another cheap Zombie arcade game, I decided to download the demo and since that day, I have been hooked. This game throws you in the midst of zombie apocolypse and lets you know your only option to survive is to group up with other characters. You then go through the game saving (or leaving) survivors and inducting them into your community which you build up, choose what to build, where to build and what base will be yours. This game takes realism to the extreme, all characters that you can switch between have their own personalities that effect how they react in situations and how their mood is during their stay in your community. They also have their own skills, weaknesses and backstories that let you know what person you want over others and let you feel a connection with these characters. With so many different personalities staying under one roof in such a severe time, problems are bound to happen and sometimes you may need to help calm down a survivor or go take them out and have a chat, maybe someone is scared or upset and needs you to give them reassurance that everything will be alright and this level of realism for what actually would happen in this situation is amazing. One thing you must keep track of is supplies, having a large community may keep it safe from zombies but starvation and illness can hurt large groups. You will need to scavange and set runners to go collect these resources to reimburse the daily supply usage.The best thing about this game is the death, in State of Decay if somone dies, they die. Runners going to get supplies and get caught up by a horde? dead. Survivor is ill and there is no supplies? Dead AND infecting others. This really gives the incentive to stay aware of whats going on and doing your best to keep everyone alive, I let my guard down when I got near the end of the game and ended up with the games first character dead because I left him alone when he needed help. There is nothing more sad than having to go collect your dead friends bag.This game is a must have for any survival lover, 10/10!

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I played this game a lot more than I thought I would but I thought it would be more worth it. This game provides an illusion of depth and replayability. It had potential to be way more dynamic and varied but fell short in the aspects it wanted to show off most. It's still worth the amount it asks for and is fun for a short while. However it definitely isn't as replayable as it would like to boast as most of what you do will start to feel like the filler content it is.State of Decay is a game with a lot of depth to characters and an interesting take on surviving an apocalypse for the "Long-Term". In my eyes it is a game where the goals were about building a strong, large community to rebuild civilization. Most zombie games I have played focused on escaping a threat or surviving relatively short terms of time without safety. State of Decay answers some of the questions of what might happen after that.The Basics of the GameThe tutorial gets you through a typical zombie panic scenario so it can focus on the main aspects of the game. The game really places focus on settling down in a base and holding your ground which is somewhat conflicting with the large map. You will quickly find strength in numbers by teaming up with a community of survivors. The character you play as cannot protect themselves alone and you'll need to take shifts with other characters so that they can heal or sleep. With the community caring for each other you are able to thrive in the apocalypse by maintaining a good base. A good base is maintained and upgraded with obvious essentials like food, fuel, ammo, medicine, and building materials. You can get these essentials by scavenging or trading. By making a strong and safe community you'll gain attention from competing communities and even the military. The military has more power and resources than anyone so gaining their attention and trust allows you to escape and ends the game's story.Conflicts and Negative PointsI felt like this game had an unclear focus for player objectives. State of Decay places a lot of focus on both exploring a huge map and settling down in a single, small base. I will say that the map for this game is absolutely huge and I was initially very impressed with how much content it had. However, exploration is encouraged but it doesn't really provide any unique incentive to do so.No incentive to explore the huge mapYou could complete the entire game by staying in one base. The benefits from moving to a different base are not very noticeable and the places you can set a base at are very limited (I think 6 or so places). Getting the largest base possible is important to have more people and facilities but the benefits for having a large base is too small. Having a different base might let you have 13 people instead of 10 but having more than 8 people is probably more than enough to easily survive. Some bases allow more facilities but it doesn't really matter as long as you have a few basic ones. Packing up your base and moving is pretty much only dependant on finding a base that can hold as much people as possible and what scenery you like to look at.There are no areas that offer unique resources. Living in one area is pretty much just as resourceful as living anywhere else. There is no reason to go somewhere far to get something valuable making less of a reason to explore the huge map.Materials for scavenging are seemingly infinite. I thrived way too easily, I had too much food and medication than I could ever need just by staying around my base. You might scavenge the area around you dry but I never reached that point. Additionally resources are randomly generated so that might be impossible.Story and Missions are lackingAt the same time the game places focus on being story driven and infinite playability. Perhaps the only part of the game that actually encourages you to explore unvisited locations is the story. However the story is extremely short and will only show you a tiny percentage of the entire map. The story will easily skip large chunks of the map which shows how useless it was to actually make the map as large as it is. The impact of the story with the rest of the game world is minimal because it struggles with trying to be infinite with filler content.The events of the story don't matter to the world. The game uses cutscenes sometimes but doesn't give them any cinematic impact. The supposed ending of the game felt as important as tying my shoe. The lack of music made story events all the less unique from the rest of the game. It was very clear that none of the story mattered after the intro which is insanely deceiving when the first moments of the game are very heavy on letting the story drive the player. After that first tutorial "chapter" it quickly feels like nothing matters.The infinite playability is advertised because of the endless respawning of 10 kinds of very simple missions. It actually felt like the game placed less emphasis on the story as an excuse to say the story doesn't matter and you are meant to endlessly play the game. State of Decay says it's dynamic by randomly generating things like events, missions, resources, and characters which would be interesting if the randomizations had more variables. The random things in this game are basic templates. You will quickly find a character who has the same voice actor as someone standing right next to you. Most characters will literally say the exact same script as someone else. Every random mission plays out the same way. A rescue mission is always a "rescue" mission and nothing unique ever changes with a mission besides the location and people involved. These missions don't even really get harder as you progress through the game. In the end, the "Dynamic" events become annoying, unoriginal filler content way too fast.I mean you can pay extra to get the DLC which adds a gradual increase in difficulty and more variety but these seem like things that should have been in the game anyways. DLC shouldn't charge to fix a game's flaws or even worse, intentionally reduce a game's core aspects for a quick buck.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												state of decay delivers an amazing story driven survival experience in the vein of tv-show "the walking dead". i was very sceptical about it, i heard about this console port gta-like zombie survival single player game. to be honest, wasnt expecting much, because i normaly play and enjoy online games, like arma, dayz, the dead linger, infestation, rust, etc.... man, was i wrong. this game brings us survival dilemas at its best.goal is similar to gta games, explore huge open world maps, play side and main missions, plus you have big group to take care about (feelings, interactions) and your shelter. you need to provide for your group many things, like securing shelter from zombies, food, workshops, guard towers, sleeping space. sometimes it gets rough, so you can try play it hero style trying to keep everyone satisfied and fed and secure, or you can try "governor" style, getting rid of "dead wood" in the group :)also, you can swith main characters, if your current one is tired or hurt much, you can go to shelter and ask someone else to take over for a while... every character has its own skills, depending what and how many actions you performed with it.survival group realism is amazing, and no bull**** there. for example my main character (group leader) died trying to help other survivor in danger. he's gone forever now, dead as dodo. no respawning or any other funny business. group keeps on surviving. play on without him, with other characters. come back and grab usefull stuff from his dead corpse, keep gruop alive.i am really amazed by concept of this game. now i am so glad this is only sp game, it has it's own thing, without all pvp and kos thing like in every other game (and we have planty of those to play that way). just try to survive and provide for your group. 10/10 (graphics could be a bit better though, and more non-console-like)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												State of Decay has some rough edges. There are some unpolished elements, some AI and glitch and design issues that could use some work. But with that disclaimer out of the way, it is essentially a hugely ambitious game that actuall pulls off so much of its goals that it makes up for its own flaws.Sewing together so many gameplay elements isn't easy - there's combat, character development, base building, resource collection, resource management, territory control, missions, more missions, side missions, auto-generated missions, plot missions, and all sorts of things you can do that will eventually become a mission if you just happen to keep busy long enough that they become important. So what, some of these many elements kind of get lost in the shuffle. I realized that if I just did my own thing, I never had to worry about resources. In fact, the biggest complaint over the radio was that I was always out of stockpile space. So, I ignored resources. And that's kind of the biggest problem with the game as well as its greatest success - it packs so much gameplay in, you simply don't have the time or the consciousness to DO everything. So I finished it in 24 hours, and it felt way to soon... after struggling for that many hours to reach the end, you relized that thtere as still so much left to do. So many things left to build, so many homes to try out, so many infestations left to clear... and I was left, in the end, wanting more. Is it a perfect game? No. But its flaws are compensated, the acting is solid, the gameplay is balanced, and it all works together to keep you having fun. I'll be looking at the DLC very soon, because I WANT MORE State of Decay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Do not take notice of the 1 hour playtime, I have worked my xbox to death playing this game. This review will focus on the gamplay and mechanics, story is not as important for this game. Lets start the review!When State of Decay first appeared on my Xbox 360 dashboard I thought of it as another cheap Zombie arcade game, I decided to download the demo and since that day, I have been hooked. This game throws you in the midst of zombie apocolypse and lets you know your only option to survive is to group up with other characters. You then go through the game saving (or leaving) survivors and inducting them into your community which you build up, choose what to build, where to build and what base will be yours. This game takes realism to the extreme, all characters that you can switch between have their own personalities that effect how they react in situations and how their mood is during their stay in your community. They also have their own skills, weaknesses and backstories that let you know what person you want over others and let you feel a connection with these characters. With so many different personalities staying under one roof in such a severe time, problems are bound to happen and sometimes you may need to help calm down a survivor or go take them out and have a chat, maybe someone is scared or upset and needs you to give them reassurance that everything will be alright and this level of realism for what actually would happen in this situation is amazing. One thing you must keep track of is supplies, having a large community may keep it safe from zombies but starvation and illness can hurt large groups. You will need to scavange and set runners to go collect these resources to reimburse the daily supply usage.The best thing about this game is the death, in State of Decay if somone dies, they die. Runners going to get supplies and get caught up by a horde? dead. Survivor is ill and there is no supplies? Dead AND infecting others. This really gives the incentive to stay aware of whats going on and doing your best to keep everyone alive, I let my guard down when I got near the end of the game and ended up with the games first character dead because I left him alone when he needed help. There is nothing more sad than having to go collect your dead friends bag.This game is a must have for any survival lover, 10/10!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												It's a decent game, but I'm still giving this one as well as the Breakdown DLC a thumbs down.The game starts out quite promising, but turns out to be repetitive and boring as soon as you've established a decent home base. The zombie sandbox seems vast at first, but excitement fades when you realize that the houses are pretty much the same everywhere. There aren't that many interesting items or people to find. And even though Breakdown seemingly adds more challenge to the game, things get pretty easy as soon as you've established a home base and started upgrading your characters. Your neighbors are super needy, you constantly need new equipment for your home base and there's always some shmuck that has to be saved or a zombie horde that has to be mowed down. In the end you just drive repetitively from one waypoint to another until you've helped everyone with their needy needs and the game is over.At worst the zombies are mildly annoying. The fight system doesn't offer much immersion. You just keep clicking and "smash spacebar not to die". The game would have benefited from a more hands on fight system like they had in Condemned.State of Decay had some redeeming qualities, mainly the way you're able to earn people's trust and create a community of survivors. The scripted events breathe life into the characters who are actually able to do some useful stuff on their own while you're completing missions. And if they die you can't bring them back. The graphics are pretty okay and there's a satisfying POK sound when your baseball bat hits an armored zombie's helmet.The game is very ambitious, and while it doesn't suck horribly, I still feel it falls short.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												I would definately recommend this game to anyone who enjoys playing zombie killing games, I loved it!A brief summary about this game: - Its singleplayer and has a great main story (it also has plenty of side missions) - It has a large open world so you can run off to explore and scavenge for resourcres when you want - During the story more new bases become available that you can move to (and upgrade to add different types of rooms eg library, garden, repairshop, etc all with different benefits) if you choose- You meet new survivors and they can join your group and you can change to control each one when you are friendly enough- Each survivor has different traits and you can choose different fight styles to level up - You can use vehicles to move around the map quickly but noise attracts zeds- There are different types of zombies to fight (eg: ones that explode) - When you exit the game real time continues ingame and so depending on how many days it is before you login different things can happen without you, usually resoucres used for different events so you need to build them up again or you need to talk to another survivor who is upset/angry and not coping well.Although there are so many alpha zombie games right now and state of decay is older and only singleplayer, I still believe its a classic and worth grabbing in a sale :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												In a world rapidly being filled with generic and increasingly boring zombie games, State of Decay is a rare gem that gets zombie survival right. It's that game that makes you a part of the world you wanted to play in after watching a good zombie flick.State of Decay is... just that zombie survival game I have been looking for. I was surprised that more people are not talking about it. Where some games get a little too caught up in humans fighting each other over resources in a post zombie-apocalypse world (like DayZ) or zombie slaughter simulation (like Dead Island and Dead Rising), State of Decay perfectly scratches that 'build a community of survivors and scavenge for resources' itch.You get to choose a location for your group to set up in, manage your resources by scavenging, building base upgrades, and helping people out in the world. Even though the game has a story - and that story is interesting to play - I found myself just exploring, scavenging, and killing some zombies.This is exactly the kind of zombie games I want to see in the future. Let's face it, the zombie genre is hot right now, and I am tired of the endless DayZ clones where you are in a zombie-themed minecraft world with the greatest danger being the other players. State of Decay gives you an open world that is exciting to explore. There are many buildings, and they are full of resources, and sometimes also full of zombies. The zombies themselves are trivial on their own, but in groups are quite deadly, and you have to take them into account when trying to figure out whether a place is worth raiding, or a route worth traveling down.Overall, I love this game, and I hope we can see a bigger, multiplayer version of it in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Great game, while I shouldn't really compare this to a game like DayZ, it introduces many zombie survival mechanics that DayZ didnt. for starters the game has a simple but good combat system, LMB to melee, RMB to aim gun and RMB + LMB to fire, there is no need to go into your inventory to de-equip a melee weapon to equip a gun as both can be used at the same time. You can also perform finishing moves with Z and dodge zombie attacks with C. The game also takes a page from L4D and has unique zombies like juggernauts who are huge zombies that can deal a lot of damage and take it at the same time, you also have screamers which attract zombies and riot zombies which are like normal zeds except that are immune to gunfire requiring melee attacks. You are required to lead the group and can make important calls like setting up multiple outposts and improving and moving homes. You have to be very careful in this game and plan out things such as routes and manouvering around zombie hordes and special zeds, one wrong move and you can have your car tipped upside down about to explode with all of your rucksacks of ammo, medicine etc. inside or even have a whole horde chasing you while you have no ammo. Not much to complain right? Well no this game isnt perfect. The game is very repetive and can get boring when you are required to do the same mission in usually the same area over and over, however this hole can be filled with the other 2 DLC that you can download and the game still has loads of replay value. Also, I found that the characters were also boring as some even had the same voices and dialogue which is a shame as they could be more unique. This is still a great game that doesnt get the praise it deserves and if we could see a State Of Decay 2 with more improvements, then you will definitely see that on my wishlist. I am currently playing this game and would recommend this to anyone looking for a cheap, singleplayer experience.Review 2:This game has only got better as I have played on. This game definetely makes zombies a huge threat unlike Day Z (sorry, I had to :0 ) and makes noise in the game have huge consequences. When you are searching containers you could make a loud noise, this causes a huge amount of zombies to swarm to your position; this is made worse by nearby hordes. I got cornered in a storage shed by 10-15 zeds because I reckless and tried to get everything quickly. My strongest character (Marcus) who has max shooting, melee and blunt weapons skills (backed up by a wrench and ak47 custom silenced) almost died from this and was seriously injured as the zeds kept attacking. This meant I couldn't take any out with my AK or wrench and had to find an small opening which was 1 door with 5% of Marcus's health remaining. This is true zombie apocalyspe survival, leaving you with near death experiences and adrenaline pumping. also, choices you make with survivors at the grange has huge consequences as Becca (sorry spoilers) died as I told Quinten she was a, oh how could I say this in the review?, an 'escort'. I now make sure I use quiet or silenced weapons as more powerful guns like the AK47 and River Snake generate a lot of noise (check the wiki for more details). Because of the noise made by the River Snake revolver, one of my group members died as zombies began to swarm us on a normal anger mangement mission. Play this game like you would with Day Z, with extreme caution and planning, as one wrong move can get you or your group members killed.Review 3: I am drawing near to the end of the game. I have actually got my chef killed at the hands of a feral which ripped him in half like a chocolate bar; now I am not sure if I want that achievment on my steam profile. I managed to build up an arsenal of weapons, which include 100+ melee weapons and 50+ guns (which include a few Automatic rifles and 2 50 Calibre rifles). fighting zombies is no easier with these guns as the ammo for my 50 cal guns are so rare that I only managed to collect 30+ rounds, this is further worsened by the guns stumbling recoil and extreme weight that can encumber a non powerhouse character. Since I am near the end I may as well just give you some tips for surviving the zombie apocalyse of State Of Decay. 1. When setting up a new home, always make sure you prioritise building a workshop and infirmary (and if possible a medical lab if you can get a library). This is because if you get injured or sick group members you can heal them back up to good health quickly, meaning they can hone their skills and do scavenging runs for you; having a workshop means you can repair your veichles which are very limited in this game aswell as make very important homemade supressors which benefit all of your characters. 2. Dont use inexperienced characters for tougher jobs. this is how my chef got killed. I sent him out to help an ally deal with a few zeds attacking her and what happens when I complete it? A feral an armoured zombies come after me and since ferals are the strongest and worst zed to face in the game, I was screwed with my 22. pistol and pipe wrench. The moral of the story is train you charcters, but always have an ally with you incase the freaks come knocking.3. USE STEALTH!!! Now yes stealth can be slow especially when scavenging, but it pays off as you will deal with less zeds and you will be less likely to get injured or killed. If there are zeds closing in on you while you are searching a container, then search it quicker and risk making noise as you will already have zombies trying to get through the doors and windows. If a horde spots you then either run away and find a car to escape or ram the horde, you could even (if you have the weapons and ammo) engage and destroy the horde so long as it doesnt attract more attention.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Interesting concept of an open world where you play as a community of survivors in a zombie apocalypse and you have scavenge resources from a small town in order to survive.  Fun melee mechanics, the shooting mechanics feel alittle awkward, in any case, using firearms is limited due to ammo and the noise. Awkward indoor camera angles make it tricky to enter a building. Main story plot is short and easily played if you are not distracted with exploring the town in your first playthrough. Various playable characters that has some depth and different skillsets. Decent graphics with good lighting, especially with a day/night cycle in game. DLC tries to introduce a game world without story plot and challenges the player to survive as long as possible. But having only one map kills much of the replayability and the exploration factor of the DLC.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game isn't just another zombie survival game.  Although there are zombies, and quite a few main survival mechanics, the core gameplay is an RPG.  You use influence points in your community to build new things, take weapons and supplies from the storage chest, and even relocate to new bases.  All-in-all, not a perfect game, but it combines the scavenging and survival aspects that I love from zombie games and combines it with RPG aspects that are very well balanced.  The open world is beautiful and does a good job of not looking too repetitive.  Also for the price of just 20 USD, who can complain about what could be hundreds of hours of gameplay?

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												I had my doubts about State of Decay, suspecting yet another shark hunting the blood of Day Z fans.  I was wrong, and I am very happy to be wrong.  I enjoy this.  It's a fair bit strategic, and a fair bit luck based.  It's all built around survival, maintaining and upgrading a base and outposts, as well as recruiting survivors to your group and keeping them happy.  Oh, and there's zombies too, and they're♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  This game is punishing, even on the easiest difficulty.  Sometimes it's downright unfair, BUT you can learn from your mistakes, learn the game, and get better.  My #1 gripe here is that there's no coop, and I hear a sequel with coop is already in the works, so we'll see.  Great buy for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												It's a decent game, but I'm still giving this one as well as the Breakdown DLC a thumbs down.The game starts out quite promising, but turns out to be repetitive and boring as soon as you've established a decent home base. The zombie sandbox seems vast at first, but excitement fades when you realize that the houses are pretty much the same everywhere. There aren't that many interesting items or people to find. And even though Breakdown seemingly adds more challenge to the game, things get pretty easy as soon as you've established a home base and started upgrading your characters. Your neighbors are super needy, you constantly need new equipment for your home base and there's always some shmuck that has to be saved or a zombie horde that has to be mowed down. In the end you just drive repetitively from one waypoint to another until you've helped everyone with their needy needs and the game is over.At worst the zombies are mildly annoying. The fight system doesn't offer much immersion. You just keep clicking and "smash spacebar not to die". The game would have benefited from a more hands on fight system like they had in Condemned.State of Decay had some redeeming qualities, mainly the way you're able to earn people's trust and create a community of survivors. The scripted events breathe life into the characters who are actually able to do some useful stuff on their own while you're completing missions. And if they die you can't bring them back. The graphics are pretty okay and there's a satisfying POK sound when your baseball bat hits an armored zombie's helmet.The game is very ambitious, and while it doesn't suck horribly, I still feel it falls short.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												Kind of buggy, kind of ugly, and kind of not exactly everything you wish it would be, State of Decay is nevertheless a great game that deserves your attention.   At first glance there is no doubt that this was a port from the Xbox 360.  The game looks like it needs a good coat of Anti-Aliasing turned way up.  The keyboard and mouse controls work, although the game feels better when played with a controller.  The game play itself is richly satisfying.    You and group of survivors, search and scavenge your way through a fairly large map dealing with mobs of zombies.   Smacking, hitting, shooting, all work well and is richly satisfying.  Zombies are not that dangerous, unless they are in a group.  There are special zombies which can be a challenge, and they keep you on your toes.  The story is… Okay…  You rescue survivors, and work on trying to figure out why the dead are eating people.  Its okay, but really what you want to do is your own thing without the story pushing you along.  Rumor has it a free mode is coming soon.  In which case, without the confides of the story, the game should becomes more enjoyable.  For $15.00 you can hardly go wrong, as there is hours worth of gameplay that goes along with it.  Give it a look.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I played this game a lot more than I thought I would but I thought it would be more worth it. This game provides an illusion of depth and replayability. It had potential to be way more dynamic and varied but fell short in the aspects it wanted to show off most. It's still worth the amount it asks for and is fun for a short while. However it definitely isn't as replayable as it would like to boast as most of what you do will start to feel like the filler content it is.State of Decay is a game with a lot of depth to characters and an interesting take on surviving an apocalypse for the "Long-Term". In my eyes it is a game where the goals were about building a strong, large community to rebuild civilization. Most zombie games I have played focused on escaping a threat or surviving relatively short terms of time without safety. State of Decay answers some of the questions of what might happen after that.The Basics of the GameThe tutorial gets you through a typical zombie panic scenario so it can focus on the main aspects of the game. The game really places focus on settling down in a base and holding your ground which is somewhat conflicting with the large map. You will quickly find strength in numbers by teaming up with a community of survivors. The character you play as cannot protect themselves alone and you'll need to take shifts with other characters so that they can heal or sleep. With the community caring for each other you are able to thrive in the apocalypse by maintaining a good base. A good base is maintained and upgraded with obvious essentials like food, fuel, ammo, medicine, and building materials. You can get these essentials by scavenging or trading. By making a strong and safe community you'll gain attention from competing communities and even the military. The military has more power and resources than anyone so gaining their attention and trust allows you to escape and ends the game's story.Conflicts and Negative PointsI felt like this game had an unclear focus for player objectives. State of Decay places a lot of focus on both exploring a huge map and settling down in a single, small base. I will say that the map for this game is absolutely huge and I was initially very impressed with how much content it had. However, exploration is encouraged but it doesn't really provide any unique incentive to do so.No incentive to explore the huge mapYou could complete the entire game by staying in one base. The benefits from moving to a different base are not very noticeable and the places you can set a base at are very limited (I think 6 or so places). Getting the largest base possible is important to have more people and facilities but the benefits for having a large base is too small. Having a different base might let you have 13 people instead of 10 but having more than 8 people is probably more than enough to easily survive. Some bases allow more facilities but it doesn't really matter as long as you have a few basic ones. Packing up your base and moving is pretty much only dependant on finding a base that can hold as much people as possible and what scenery you like to look at.There are no areas that offer unique resources. Living in one area is pretty much just as resourceful as living anywhere else. There is no reason to go somewhere far to get something valuable making less of a reason to explore the huge map.Materials for scavenging are seemingly infinite. I thrived way too easily, I had too much food and medication than I could ever need just by staying around my base. You might scavenge the area around you dry but I never reached that point. Additionally resources are randomly generated so that might be impossible.Story and Missions are lackingAt the same time the game places focus on being story driven and infinite playability. Perhaps the only part of the game that actually encourages you to explore unvisited locations is the story. However the story is extremely short and will only show you a tiny percentage of the entire map. The story will easily skip large chunks of the map which shows how useless it was to actually make the map as large as it is. The impact of the story with the rest of the game world is minimal because it struggles with trying to be infinite with filler content.The events of the story don't matter to the world. The game uses cutscenes sometimes but doesn't give them any cinematic impact. The supposed ending of the game felt as important as tying my shoe. The lack of music made story events all the less unique from the rest of the game. It was very clear that none of the story mattered after the intro which is insanely deceiving when the first moments of the game are very heavy on letting the story drive the player. After that first tutorial "chapter" it quickly feels like nothing matters.The infinite playability is advertised because of the endless respawning of 10 kinds of very simple missions. It actually felt like the game placed less emphasis on the story as an excuse to say the story doesn't matter and you are meant to endlessly play the game. State of Decay says it's dynamic by randomly generating things like events, missions, resources, and characters which would be interesting if the randomizations had more variables. The random things in this game are basic templates. You will quickly find a character who has the same voice actor as someone standing right next to you. Most characters will literally say the exact same script as someone else. Every random mission plays out the same way. A rescue mission is always a "rescue" mission and nothing unique ever changes with a mission besides the location and people involved. These missions don't even really get harder as you progress through the game. In the end, the "Dynamic" events become annoying, unoriginal filler content way too fast.I mean you can pay extra to get the DLC which adds a gradual increase in difficulty and more variety but these seem like things that should have been in the game anyways. DLC shouldn't charge to fix a game's flaws or even worse, intentionally reduce a game's core aspects for a quick buck.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Open world, third person survival zombie game with choice based missions.- Has a story and a plot, that goes like most good zombie series.- Day/night cycle. Zombies become more aggressive at night.- Kill, explore, gain allies, gather ressources and build bases/outposts.- Switch between characters. Life, stamina and injuries are essential factors.- Skill system for each character making them good at different tasks.- Use cars to drive around the map and slaughter zombies.- A lot of different weapons including swords, machetes, snipers, shotguns, assault rifles, grenade launchers etc.In generel good/bad:- A lot to explore. The gameplay is addictive and fun.- Graphics are ok and sounds are good. - Controls not the best, but can be played. Cars are stiff in handling. (console port).- It has no MP, but does not need it, as the SP is satisfying long enough, to keep you going.Similar game(s): - It reminds me a bit of Dead Island, which I played on the PS3. That game went more fluid for me than this one.However Dead Island is much more linear than State of Decay. Also Dead Island is easier than State of Decay.Score: 9/10.

												This game is completely amazing! Nothing more satisfying than hearing the music ramp up as I knee zombies in the face, splattering beautiful guts all over the place with a marvelous crush sound. The sounds and animations are completely gorgeous and well done, using a sword and slicing through zombies feels sooooooooooo damn good!The game takes good things from all sorts of genres, it has great elements of role playing, strategy, action, survival, shooters and even stealth sims. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I really like how this game focuses on survival and fighting off zombies. Once you build a community you have to go out and gather ressources to survive, and don't be careless out there because you will get overrun and killed. The fighting system is really simple and fun wether you choose to go melee or use guns. The zombies animations and movements are nice and fluid and thier artificial intelligence is simple and well done. They react to sound and light and will run to you if you make too much noise. You can still sneak around them, especially in the dark and score a few stealth melee kills wich is always nice. I also like how you can choose to build your community by finding more survivor, controlling certain characters to level them up and get them to learn new abilities and be stronger. You have quite a big map to explore as well, a lot of scavenging to do. You have to be carefull to keep the zombie population in check around your home base so it doesn't get overrun. The gameplay is really fun and well done. And of course, among all of that, you have a nice little quest story line that gets you to learn about what  happened and what caused all this. Although not everything is answered at the end of the game it opens the door for a nice sequel or expansion. I give this game a 9 out of 10 because the only downside is that you cannot bring your friends to play with you in co-op... how awesome would it have been.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												OK, quick PROS/CONS review:PROS:-Solid zombie experience, sound mechanics works just fine-Decent size map, with well designed details-Good looking game, well ported-Satisfying combat -Good price for what you get (specially if it's on sale)-DLCs give good replayability, Lifeline brings a new urban map-Tons of different weapons-Dozens of different characters to play with, some of them randomly generated-Well developed survivor community mechanics-An easy fight can go south very quickly, making it more immersiveCONS:-After about 50% of the main game, "standard zombie story" becomes "weak and poor zombie story"-Some loading issues in specific areas, dangerous specially while driving-GUI/commands scream "controller" and focuses on multiuse keys-The camera tends to be quite uncomfortable in tight spaces, and when aiming in CQC-Driving experience is barely sufficient (some cars have ridiculous handling/behaviour)-Zombie animations sometimes bug with the terrain or obstacles-Looks a little dated despite the use of Cry Engine 3-After some hours, it can get repetitive. I found starting from scratch to be more entertaining than late endgame-The other survivors' AI can be stupid quite often, getting themselves chewed on with ease Minor stuff I complain about and might not be so important for you:-Unrealistic/cartoonish looks for some of you out there (they're ok, but...)-Lack of easily visible explanations for advanced controls (ie combos)-Almost half of the mechanics aren't explained anywhere (ie outpost resources and their costs)-Zombies sometimes spawn right behind you following the sound mechanics, but the place was just clear...-Cars can make things all too easy sometimes, killing bunch of zombies in one go-Lack of hard-to-reach places, special points of interest, "secrets", etc-Unsatisfying main storyline ending, at least in my opinionIf you've read this far, why not give you some more text...This game feels like bunch of good ideas but with just a decent execution. It could have been much, much better with more work, yet I guess the original console constraints took that away. However, IT WORKS. It's a cool zombie experience, it has many classic stuff like hordes of zeds assaulting a position that you need to barricade and fight for, hit n' run rescue missions and the (not so classical) special zeds, that actually reminded me a lot of Dead Island. You get a really good game for the 20 bucks price tag, that is very fun to play and despite being easy at times, it can also be very punishing. Sometimes you're Rambo, sometimes you're Deadmeat. Watch yourself out there.There is another small Pro, and that is the Mod community. It's still small, but it will grow and that will only extend the game's life. If you're handy with that stuff, check the Nexus Mods.I'd say it's a solid 8/10. Absolutely recommended for zombie lovers out there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Ok so as you can see I've racked up nearly 160 hours on this game. Addicted? Possibly!So where to begin. I don't think its worth me providing you with a "good" & "bad" list because a lot of that will down to personal taste. The game to me is delicious and is best played via the Breakdown DLC. The storyline is ok, but it's merely a filler. The game is all about survival and you don't need a plot for that. The Graphics are decent enough and while I'm sure someone with attention to detail may be able to point out some issues with them, they do the job well and you feel immersed.Unlike a lot of Zombie games I've played, this isn't all about melee. There are tons of weapons too but like everything in this game you have to find them, and the ammo too. By far one of my favourite things about this game is that more or less every building can be entered and the loot from each is completely random every play through. Sure there are hotspots fo some of the loot in the game, but it doesnt detract from the fact that you have to hunt them down, carry them home and do it with zombies crawling all over you.I've had the chance to play with mods too and found one which gave me the ability to disable the "special" zombies. While these present a decent challenge and are great additions, they can at times be a bit overkill with 2 out of the 4 able to kill even your highest level character in just a few hits. I could go on and on about this game... I'm still playing it and expect I'll be close to 1000 hours before I tire of it, if not beyond. There is a new DLC on the way too with a new map (sweet) so this will just refresh the game for me. The forums are also alive with both friendly players and staff so you are never far from help.If like me you want a survival challenge, want it with Zombies and on a reasonably large map (we always want bigger and better Undead Labs :P) then don't look anywhere else. I've searched long and hard for a game of this type, and this ticks most of the boxes for me. I'd be really surprised if you were disappointed.Hope this review was useful and if you buy the game... enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Do you like DayZ or H1Z1?  Do you need a break from getting killed every 20 minutes by mean random people?  Get this game! This game is a survival game kind of like DayZ but it is single player.  Because of this, it seems to be more polished.  It's a finished game so the graphics look a lot better than early access.  You don't have food and stamina bars, instead you have to find enough food, meds, water, and other stuff for your settlement of survivors.  It's really cool to play this game because you aren't just thinking about your survival, you are thinking of all of the people in your group.  You can also get supplies and build up your base.  Even in a single player game, you feel like you are part of a group because you are always getting supplies for other people.Since this is single player, you get all of the loot!  It's awesome that you don't have to play for 2 hours just to find a can of beans like in other survival games.  The game has perma death, so each time you die with a character he never comes back.  You don't have to start over, you just have to play as another person in your group.  Even though this game doesn't have a great story, what's there is okay, and I felt a lot of tension becasue I didn't want these characters to die.  It also means that if you play this game you will have a different outcome on every playthrough.  It won't really change the story much, but you can level up each survivor differently to add variety to your gameplay.  There are some technical issues here.  I have a pretty powerful laptop that is about equal to the recommended system requirements, but I still had to mod the game to get a respectable framrate.  You will have to mess around with the game to get it to run.  Luckily, the nexus now supports mod for this (and apparantly for any) game.  You can get a mod that disables shadows that will double your framerate easily.  The game is poorly optimised, and keep that in mind if your machine is closer to the minimum requirements.  I have to recommend this game.  I really like survival games, but was getting tired of all the mmo titles because people are jerks.  If you want to change up your survival experience, this is the perfect game for that.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2013
												I will have to say this is the first time I got a "early acess" game. So far the experience has been good.  I won't rate this game because it is unfinished. However things are looking up for this game.  It has good play mechanics that are unique for zombie games. Others have described it by comparing it to various other zombie games. In all fairness I have to say its got its own flavor and i don't really find the experince repetitive of other games. I recommend  this unfinished game highly i'm sure the finished version will please many zombie fans even more than it does in its current state which is very satisfing game exprience as it is.UPDATE: OK i've had this game a long time now and it's been finished now as well as had a few DLC release for it. So with out further stalling here's my breakdown. The Good: Great story that doesn't hit you in the head with trying to explain zombies.Lots of characters to play as.Nice Tired/food/water mechanic that doesn't consume your game time.Gorgeous graphics. The bad: Seemed a bit short start to finish. I highly recommend you grab the DLC to extent this one.Random graphic slow downs despite having a powerful system. Harsh HDR lighting, some games get this tuned right some don't While this game does look great the contrast  from HDR can be a bit much at times.       Overall I give this game an 82%. Zombie fans wil love it and non zombie fans will stil find it a enjoyable experience.

												If you like zombie slaying and saving survivors, but always wanted the experience to be a bit more personal, this game is for you.SoD gives a satisfying level of depth to saving people and character building, something largely missing from more acrade style shooters of this type. The base building and resource management is a constant source of both pressure and accomplishment; trying to house, feed supply and develop 20+ people is a challenge.Time becomes a big issue in this game, you won't have enough of it be everywhere and do everything, some things simply have to be prioritized. You may WANT to help those farmers out, but you have a team member in trouble and your base is nearly out of food and ammo...All up, SoD is a pretty well rounded sandboxey survivor sim. Few bugs to speak of, and I've never felt this invested in a zombie game before.  Definite thumbs up.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												One if not the best single player zombie survival game out there. It has all the features of the old school z survivals such as going out to scavange resources, establishing outposts, fortificating buildings, etc. The graphics are amazing, it has a great storyline and while it can be a bit heavy to bear at times the next day you want to play it again. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing, keeping the calm moments calm and the thrill to danger when zeds are nearby. The Breakdown expansion is what the survival experts and fans want here. Little to no story line, focus on long-term survival and pretty limited resources are what make this game and the DLC great. If you are looking for the Zombie Outbreak Survival game but don't want to go like DayZ with other people, this is the game you want.

												To date, this game is the best re-creation of the feel of the AMC series, "The Walking Dead".  This is one of the finest indie games I have played and better than a lot of stuff out of huge mega corps.This is a gather resource/build community/follow multithreaded adventure model. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												This game is fairly straight forward, you switch between a number of survivors in the zombie apocalypse where you must seek out resources and fight off zombies to preserve and expand your base. Your resources dwindle day by day and you must be strategic in prioritizing which resources you pursue. This game excels because of its simplicity but that simplicity unfortunately leads to the game becoming repetative later on with no clear goals and no further progression. The underlying mechanics of the game remind me of mobile games but with much stronger graphics and interface. The game feels repetitive once you have an established base and full group of survivors, which can happen pretty quickly if you want it to. At this point you're really just playing to keep the game going because while there is a story mode there is no clear objective besides just surviving. The game would really benefit from a more comprehensive base building element or something that maybe gives you a sense of rebuilding society or fighting back a gainst the zombies in a meaningful way, but then I guess it deviate from the norms of the zombie-sirvival genre. Zombies just keep spawning and after a point you'll feel like you've killed more zombies than the population of the little country towns of the setting. Combat leans more in favor of melee as noises will draw the hordes. I like the combat mechanics that give you the right level of contectual animation, when you swing at a hoard of zombies the way you swing takes into consideration how you're moving and how the zombies are moving around you. Driving takes a little getting used to but reminds me of how the driving feels in the GTA games. Vehicles are as much a resources as ammunition, food, medical, and building supplies with a finite number of them that dwindle as you wreck them. People are also as much a resource that you must weigh whether to allow them into your group and if and when you prioritize aid over your own resource gathering.I bought the game for $7 and its worth a bit more than that, but not too much.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												OK, quick PROS/CONS review:PROS:-Solid zombie experience, sound mechanics works just fine-Decent size map, with well designed details-Good looking game, well ported-Satisfying combat -Good price for what you get (specially if it's on sale)-DLCs give good replayability, Lifeline brings a new urban map-Tons of different weapons-Dozens of different characters to play with, some of them randomly generated-Well developed survivor community mechanics-An easy fight can go south very quickly, making it more immersiveCONS:-After about 50% of the main game, "standard zombie story" becomes "weak and poor zombie story"-Some loading issues in specific areas, dangerous specially while driving-GUI/commands scream "controller" and focuses on multiuse keys-The camera tends to be quite uncomfortable in tight spaces, and when aiming in CQC-Driving experience is barely sufficient (some cars have ridiculous handling/behaviour)-Zombie animations sometimes bug with the terrain or obstacles-Looks a little dated despite the use of Cry Engine 3-After some hours, it can get repetitive. I found starting from scratch to be more entertaining than late endgame-The other survivors' AI can be stupid quite often, getting themselves chewed on with ease Minor stuff I complain about and might not be so important for you:-Unrealistic/cartoonish looks for some of you out there (they're ok, but...)-Lack of easily visible explanations for advanced controls (ie combos)-Almost half of the mechanics aren't explained anywhere (ie outpost resources and their costs)-Zombies sometimes spawn right behind you following the sound mechanics, but the place was just clear...-Cars can make things all too easy sometimes, killing bunch of zombies in one go-Lack of hard-to-reach places, special points of interest, "secrets", etc-Unsatisfying main storyline ending, at least in my opinionIf you've read this far, why not give you some more text...This game feels like bunch of good ideas but with just a decent execution. It could have been much, much better with more work, yet I guess the original console constraints took that away. However, IT WORKS. It's a cool zombie experience, it has many classic stuff like hordes of zeds assaulting a position that you need to barricade and fight for, hit n' run rescue missions and the (not so classical) special zeds, that actually reminded me a lot of Dead Island. You get a really good game for the 20 bucks price tag, that is very fun to play and despite being easy at times, it can also be very punishing. Sometimes you're Rambo, sometimes you're Deadmeat. Watch yourself out there.There is another small Pro, and that is the Mod community. It's still small, but it will grow and that will only extend the game's life. If you're handy with that stuff, check the Nexus Mods.I'd say it's a solid 8/10. Absolutely recommended for zombie lovers out there.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Now that I've got a solid number of hours under my belt and played the crap out of breakdown i feel more confident in giving a review. This game is buggy as hell. This game needs patches. BADLY. Driving a vehicle will cause your framerate to drop. Driving a vehicle is also dangerous because giving certain objects the lightest tap can send you and your vehicle into LOW ORBIT. There are also multiple texture glitches that cause large black squares to appear on the ground. Often times during combat, you will notice your weapon passing harmlessly trhough enemies allowing them to latch onto your backside and chew on you.During missions it is also possible for the waypoint to fling itself off the minimap and thus become unreachable, making it difficult to complete the mission. It can also become permanently stuck on the map after completion of the mission making it IMPOSSIBLE TO COMPLETE ANOTHER MISSION UNTIL AFTER GAME RESTART. Oh and did we mention you can't save during a mission? This means you'll lose an untold amount of progess.Certain LAUNCHER errors can cause the game to crash an hour or two after it launches. TLDR HEY DEVS FIX THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME! In spite of all the glitches and bugs I still love playing it and 30 hours in I am still nowhere near done playing it. Definitely got my money's worth playing this game. Just wish they would fix some♥♥♥♥♥♥My advice? Buy it, it is a fun game, it just needs more polishing. The DLC is good too, I can't get enough of Breakdown.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												This game is simply too much fun. I have not found any glaring faults as yet, though I do wish vehicles carried more items (a kitchen timer should not really take up the same space as a duffle bag in the back of a pickup truck) and that fully metal weapons, such as a pipe, lasted far, far longer than they do.Deaths are real, and as a character dies you are stuck with whomever is left. While that does not change the game itself, it does limit what you are able to do later in the game if you have not been working on all the available characters' skills. I consider this a bonus, as it prevents the game from getting boring.Vehicle stability is reminiscent of Grand Theft Auto. This is a good thing.I have not played The Walking Dead series, so I have no basis for comparison. All I can really say, is that I have a ton of fun in this game.

												Very addictive and clever Zombie Apocalypse simulation. For those wondering it's pretty much Grand Theft Auto meets your favorite zombie simultor (Day Z / War Z). Don't take State of Decay lightly, it has the true "end of the world" environment, meaningful missions, crafting, weapon decay, group management and so much more.Where Dayz and War Z fail, State of Decay excels! True randomization of enemy hordes that actually make zombies a REAL threat. Lack of ammunition, food, and other supplys force the player to take real care in their movements to prevent the loss of their group. One your favorite character dies the story continues on without themIn my personal opinion if you are a fan of the zombie genre you should pick this little gem up immediately.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This game is amazing. For a smaller studio this is really a very worthwile venture. The game puts you into a familiar zombie apocalypse. Only this time, you not only work with your team to kill zombies... but together to survive for the long haul. Killing zombies may be a necessity at times but it is no way a major goal of this game. If you can collect food, fuel, materials, medicine and/or ammo without combat, more power to you. Build your base. Place strategic outposts. Then Outlast.The game has a fresh experience to a very familiar genre. I actually felt anxiety at the prospect of losing a favored character. (damn ferals!) For when they die, the are G.O.N.E. to great beyond. It's the "one more turn" sort of action that makes 4 hrs go by in a blink. The only major drawbacks is that to some the action may be to similiar sometimes. However, different characters can be affected by your decisions and the challenges you choose. Secondly, there is a big lack of a in game guide/help screen. This is the real short coming of the developer as this would be simple enough to fix.Overall, worth it's full price in my mind. This is what the Walking Dead should have put out as their game (aside from the TellTale which was amazing, this should have been Survival Instinct) I can't wait for a new map.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												State of Decay is a great game. There is a great, open-world to explore, a church to upgrade, and yes, plenty of zombies to kill.  However, there are a few issues in the game, primarily the frame rate and zombie teleporting. The frame rate drops out of nowhere, stooping to rates of 5-10, though only for a second (long enough for you to get your neck chewed off).  Also, zombies to teleport and respawn almost instantainously, without your realizing. One for instance, popped right in front of me when I was barricaiding a room. Finally for the issues, there is perma-death.  That means, when you dead, YOU DEAD!!! But, none of these minor problems should stop you from playing one of the best zombie games in history.  Combat is fluid, and the ground take-downs are sick.  The amount of blood and gore also makes each swing of a spiked bat murderous and powerful.  Probably one of the game's highest strong points is the sound.  Each moan of a zombie and the shuffiling of the footsteps make your heart skip a beat and wonder where the heck that one (or two, or three) zombie is at.  All and all, State of Decay is an amazing game and an even better zombie survival RPG, witch shouldn't be passed up because of a few minor bugs.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Open world, third person survival zombie game with choice based missions.- Has a story and a plot, that goes like most good zombie series.- Day/night cycle. Zombies become more aggressive at night.- Kill, explore, gain allies, gather ressources and build bases/outposts.- Switch between characters. Life, stamina and injuries are essential factors.- Skill system for each character making them good at different tasks.- Use cars to drive around the map and slaughter zombies.- A lot of different weapons including swords, machetes, snipers, shotguns, assault rifles, grenade launchers etc.In generel good/bad:- A lot to explore. The gameplay is addictive and fun.- Graphics are ok and sounds are good. - Controls not the best, but can be played. Cars are stiff in handling. (console port).- It has no MP, but does not need it, as the SP is satisfying long enough, to keep you going.Similar game(s): - It reminds me a bit of Dead Island, which I played on the PS3. That game went more fluid for me than this one.However Dead Island is much more linear than State of Decay. Also Dead Island is easier than State of Decay.Score: 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I really like how this game focuses on survival and fighting off zombies. Once you build a community you have to go out and gather ressources to survive, and don't be careless out there because you will get overrun and killed. The fighting system is really simple and fun wether you choose to go melee or use guns. The zombies animations and movements are nice and fluid and thier artificial intelligence is simple and well done. They react to sound and light and will run to you if you make too much noise. You can still sneak around them, especially in the dark and score a few stealth melee kills wich is always nice. I also like how you can choose to build your community by finding more survivor, controlling certain characters to level them up and get them to learn new abilities and be stronger. You have quite a big map to explore as well, a lot of scavenging to do. You have to be carefull to keep the zombie population in check around your home base so it doesn't get overrun. The gameplay is really fun and well done. And of course, among all of that, you have a nice little quest story line that gets you to learn about what  happened and what caused all this. Although not everything is answered at the end of the game it opens the door for a nice sequel or expansion. I give this game a 9 out of 10 because the only downside is that you cannot bring your friends to play with you in co-op... how awesome would it have been.

												This game is completely amazing! Nothing more satisfying than hearing the music ramp up as I knee zombies in the face, splattering beautiful guts all over the place with a marvelous crush sound. Some missions and when or where they pop up are really annoying. losing characters is very sad (kind of a good thing maybe), carrying rucksacks gets very old, NPCs on scavenger missions just stand there even with zombies around. Overall though, I might complain, but the game is so completely awesome, it's so good that any problem feels meaningless.GREAT GAME.
